awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: The Pteridological Collections Consortium: An integrative approach to pteridophyte diversity over the last 420 million years
awd_abstract_narration:
Ferns and their relatives ("pteridophytes") arose approximately 420 million years ago and were the dominant plant groups for hundreds of millions of years afterwards. Today the pteridophytes are outnumbered by the diversity and abundance of other plant groups, such as those that bear flowers, but they remain diverse (with around 12,000 species), ecologically important, and are found throughout the world. This Thematic Collections Network (TCN) brings together 9 core institutions whose goal is to make digital images and data on the distribution and biology of 1.6 million fossil and modern ferns and their relatives available to researchers. This effort includes 39 US Museums and Herbaria that will provide on-line access of collections data to researchers worldwide who will be able to address pressing questions about the evolution, distribution, and biology of land plants.  This project would train students and reach the public through teacher training opportunities, the development of curriculum and education boxes and through the production of informative science videos. 

The Pteridological Collections Consortium TCN is an interdisciplinary initiative that will database, image, and disseminate information on an unprecedented number of extant and fossil pteridophyte specimens. The combining of neo- and paleobotanical collections data will produce an online resource via a Symbiota framework to enable research on the distribution, ecology, genetics, and deep-time evolution of an important group of vascular plants. Pteridophytes are important because they 1) are relatively diverse and have extensive global distributions, 2) are associated with evolutionary innovations that shaped adaptations to terrestrial ecosystems, 3) they are sensitive to local environmental conditions and play important roles in modern communities, and 4) they have an excellent fossil record for addressing deep-time questions. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ferns and their relatives ("pteridophytes") arose approximately 420 million years ago and were the dominant plant groups for hundreds of millions of years afterwards. Today the pteridophytes are outnumbered by the diversity and abundance of other plant groups, such as those that bear flowers, but they remain diverse. There are an estimated 12,000 species found throughout the world and they represent an ecologically important group of plants. In many ecosystems they form a dominant and conspicuous part of the environment. Field Museum is one of 9 core institutions as part of a Thematic Collections Network (TCN) that has the overall goal to make digital images and data on the distribution and biology of 1.6 million fossil and modern ferns and their relatives available to researchers, educators and the general public. This effort includes 39 US Museums and Herbaria that provide on-line access of collections data to researchers worldwide who will be able to address pressing questions about the evolution, distribution, and biology of land plants.

Significantly, Field Museum has professionally trained dozens of students in collection management, imaging, and databasing. This provided an insight and opportunity to be exposed to a world class natural history museum and collections-based research and management. Many students are known to have leveraged this opportunity to pursue graduate programs or continue their career in STEM. Field Museum has led several broader impact initiatives ranging from developing lesson plans and digital learning tools and resources to popular public transcription campaigns that also led to widespread popular media coverage. The unfortunate circumstances of the global COVID-19 pandemic did lend itself to popular virtual events and activities, where students, families and the general public could participate remotely and help transcribe scientific label data from digitized specimens. Importantly, this provided opportunities to help connect and educate the general public to the significance of scientific natural history collections and their positive impact on society.

Field Museum has made publicly available almost 14,000 fossil specimen records under the auspices of the project with 22,200 images produced directly during the project period, and is complemented by a further 8,200 images. Field Museum also coordinated with two subaward institutions, Michigan State University and the Wisconsin State Herbarium, University of Wisconsin. Field Museum has made a total of 103,500 fern herbarium specimens records publicly available representing extant species (still in existence; surviving).  Similarly, the Wisconsin State Herbarium, University of Wisconsin has almost 30,000 fern records and Michigan State has almost 16,500 fern records publicly available. Together, this represents approximately 150,000 digital fern herbarium records.

 

The Pteridological Collections Consortium TCN is an interdisciplinary initiative that continues to database, image, and disseminate information on an unprecedented number of extant and fossil pteridophyte specimens. The combining of neo- and paleobotanical collections data has produced an online resource via a Symbiota framework to enable research on the distribution, ecology, genetics, and deep-time evolution of an important group of vascular plants. Data can be directly accessed from the Pteridophyte Collections Consortium (PCC) portal, i.e., https://www.pteridoportal.org/ Pteridophytes are important because they 1) are relatively diverse and have extensive global distributions, 2) are associated with evolutionary innovations that shaped adaptations to terrestrial ecosystems, 3) they are sensitive to local environmental conditions and play important roles in modern communities, and 4) they have an excellent fossil record for addressing deep-time questions. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award is available through the national resource (iDigBio.org) as well as global data aggregators such as the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF).
